Question 2.Question:
A carpenter on top of a roof 20.0m high dropped a hammer of mass 1.5kg and it fell freely to the ground. The kinetic energy of the hammer just before hitting the ground is ……

[g = 10ms-2]
Question 2.Explanation:
Before hitting the floor K.E = P.E

½ mv2 = mgh

v2 = 2gh

v2 = 2 x 10 x 20

v2 = 400

K.E = ½ mv2

= ½ 1.5 (400)

= 300J

Options.Value: X will be 500m ahead of Y
X and Y will both be 500m from the point of throw
X and Y will be 500m from each other
Y will be 500m ahead of X

Question 3.Question: Two balls X and Y weighing 5g and 50kg respectively were thrown up vertically at the same time with a velocity of 100ms-1. How will their position be one second later?
Question 3.Explanation:
Recall, v2 = u2 – 2gs

0 = 1002 – 2 x 10 x s = 10,000 – 20s

s = (10000)/20 = 500m

This is independent of mass. The two bodies where acted upon by the same retarding force of gravity which is independent of mass of the body; therefore both will be 500 m from the point of throw.

Options.Value: There is no reaction from the floor of the lift
There is no gravitational pull on the man in the lift
The inside of the lift is air tight
The lift is in vacuum

Question 4.Question: A man standing on a lift that is descending does not feel any weight because
Question 4.Explanation: There is no gravitational pull on the man in the lift.

13.0N
14.0N
10.0N

Question 5.Question: The diagram above shows two vectors at right angles to each other. The value of the resultant vector is
Question 5.Explanation:
Resolution of forces acting perpendicularly to each other

Using Pythagoras theorem to get the resultant

R2 = A2 + B2

R2 = 62 + 82

R = √6 2+82

=√36+64

= √100

= 10N

Question 6.Question: An object of mass 2kg moves with a velocity of 10ms-1 round of a circle of radius 4m. Calculate the centripetal force on the object.
Question 6.Explanation:
Centripetal force, F = mv 2/r

= (2 x 102)/4

= 100/2

= 50N

Question 7.Question: If it takes an object 3s to fall freely to the ground from a certain height, what is the distance covered by the object? [g = 10ms-2]
Question 7.Explanation:
Third equation of motion, S = ut + 1/2gt2

S = 0 x 3 + ( ½ x 10 x 32)

S = 5 x 9

= 45m

Z only

Question 8.Explanation: A body is said to be in neutral equilibrium if it returns to its original position when slightly displaced.

Question 9.Question: If a tube of small radius opened at both ends is placed in a liquid, the liquid will
Question 9.Explanation: This phenomena is known as the capillarity action of the tube with the liquid. Capillary action occurs when the adhesion to the walls is stronger than the cohesive forces between the liquid molecules. The height to which capillary action will take water in a uniform circular tube (picture to right) is limited by surface tension and, of course, gravity.

Question 12.Question: A machine is used to lift a load of 20N through a height of 10m. If the efficiency of the machine is 40%, how much work is done?
Question 12.Explanation:
Efficiency of a machine is given as;

Efficiency = work output/work input x 100%

or

E = work done by load/work done by effort x 100%

or

E = (load x distance moved by load)/work done by effort) x 100%

40/100 = (20 x 10)/work input

0.4 = 200/work input

Work input = 200/0.4

Work input = 500 J

Options.Value: Water
Petrol
Kerosene
Grease

Question 13.Explanation: Grease reduces friction. It has high viscosity and its layers slide across one another making it a good lubricant.

Question 14.Question:
A copper wire was subjected to a tensile stress of 7.7 x 107Nm-2. Calculate the tensile strain of the wire.

[Young modulus = 1.1 x 1011 Nm-2]
Question 14.Explanation:
Young modulus = stress/strain

1.1 x 1011 = 7.7 x 107/strain

Strain = 7.7 x 107/1.1 x 1011

Strain = 7 x 10-4

Options.Value: 220N
80N
50N
520N

Question 15.Question:
An object weighs 22kg in water and 30kg in air. What is the upthrust exerted by the liquid on the object?

[g = 10ms-2]
Question 15.Explanation:
Upthrust = loss in weight when immersed in water

Weight in water = mass in water x acceleration due to gravity

= 22 x 10 = 220 N

Weight in air = mass in air x acceleration due to gravity

= 30 x 10

= 300N

Upthrust = weight in air – weight in water

= 300 -220

= 80N

Options.Value: 100JK-1
200JK-1
900JK -1
90JK-1

Question 16.Question: A block of aluminum is heated electrically by a 30W heater. If the temperature rises by 10oC in 5 minutes, the heat capacity of the aluminum is
Question 16.Explanation:
Law of conservation of energy, heat capacity = electrical energy

Qπø= pt

Q = pt/πø

P = IV

Q = IVt/πø

Q = (30 x 5 x 60)/ 10

Q = 900Jk-1

Options.Value: White body
Red body
Conductor
Black body

Question 17.Explanation: Black bodies absorb heat than other form of bodies while brightly coloured objects absorb heat poorly.

Question 19.Question: If the volume of a gas increases steadily as the temperature decreases at constant pressure, the gas obeys
Question 19.Explanation:
Charles' law shows the relationship between the volume of a gas and the temperature.

It states that the volume of a given mass of gas is directly proportional to the temperature provided the temperature remains constant.

V α T

Where k is the constant of proportionality,

V = KT

V/T = K

Question 20.Question: Steam burn is more severe than that of boiling water because
Question 20.Explanation: Steam has a negligible mass making the energy to mass ratio greater than that of a liquid. Steam is more likely to cause burn injuries than boiling water because of the latent heat of vaporization. Since water expands to approximately 1,600 times its volume when it turns from liquid to steam, steam often escapes its container under pressure.

Question 22.Explanation: The earth loses its heat to the environment at night by radiation as the environment remains cool as the earth is a good conductor of heat and bad retainer of heat.

Question 23.Question: The product PV where P is pressure and V is volume, has the same unit as
Question 23.Explanation:
PV = pressure x volume

But pressure = force/area

∴ PV = (force/area) x volume = (force x volume)/area

But volume/area = distance

∴ PV = force x distance

Which is the same as energy.

Options.Value: I,III and IV
I, II and IV
I, II, III and IV
I, II and III

Question 25.Question: When the human eye loses its power of accommodation, the defect is known as
Question 25.Explanation: Presbyopia is an eye defect that is caused when the eye loses its power of accommodation, by the hardening of the lenses due to old age. Astigmatism is a common vision problem caused by an error in the shape of the cornea. It causes blurry, fuzzy or distorted vision at any distance.

Question 26.Question: A length of wire has frequency of 255Hz when stretched by a force of 225N. If the force increases to 324N, what is the new frequency of vibration?
Question 26.Explanation:
The relationship between the tension (force) and the frequency in a string is given as.

F α T1/2

F = KT1/2

K= F/T1/2

F1/T11/2 = F2/T21/2

255/(225)1/2 = F2/(324)1/2

F2 = 255 x (324)1/2/(225)1/2

= 306 Hz

Options.Value: 0.03D
0.04D
0.06D
0.02D

Question 28.Question: Which of the following electromagnetic waves has the highest frequency?
Question 28.Explanation:
From the electromagnetic spectrum;

- Gamma rays have the shortest wavelength and highest frequency.

- X-rays have lesser frequency than gamma rays but have longer wavelengths.

- Ultra violet rays have lesser frequency than X-rays but have longer wavelengths.

- Light rays have lesser frequency than ultra violet rays but have longer wavelengths.

- Infrared rays have lesser frequency than light rays but have longer wavelengths.

- Radio waves have the longest wavelength and the least frequency in the series.

Options.Value: Magenta
Yellow
Red
Blue

Question 29.Question: When a red rose flower is observed in blue light, what colour does the observer see?
Question 29.Explanation: All other colours are absorbed living it with the red. The colour which an object presents to the eye is the colour of light it reflects. Red rose flower will therefore absorb any other colour and reflect red. Therefore, when viewed in blue light, it has no colour to reflect and will therefore appear black. Although mixture of red light and blue light will give magenta.

Options.Value: Moon is not completely hidden in the earth's shadow
Moon's umbra falls on some part of the earth
Moon is between the sun and the earth
Earth is between the sun and the moon

Question 30.Explanation: The eclipse of the sun also known as solar eclipse is caused when the moon is between the earth and the sun.

Question 31.Question:
A cannon is fired from X. After how long is the sound heard at a town Y 4.95 km away?

[Velocity of sound in air = 330ms-1]
Question 31.Explanation:
Velocity = distance/time

Distance = 4.95 km or 4,950m

330 = 4,950/time

Time = 4,950/330

Time = 15 seconds

Options.Value: 16cm
14cm
10cm
25cm

Question 32.Question: An image in a convex lens is upright and magnified 3 times. If the focal length of the lens is 15cm, what is the object distance?
Question 32.Explanation:
Assuming the object is Xcm

Being magnified

Using Magnification formula,

M = v/u

3 = v/x

v = 3x

Taking note that magnification in a convex lens the image is virtual

v = -3x

From lens formula, 1/f = 1/v + 1/u

1/15 = 1/-3X + 1/X

1/15 = 1 + (-3)/-3X

1/15 = -2/-3X

1/15 = 2/3X

x = 1/15 x 3/2

x = 0.1m

x = 10cm

Options.Value: 3.0
2.0
0.3
6.0

Question 33.Question: The capacitance of a parallel plate capacitor is 20µF in air and 60µF in the presence of a dielectric. What is the dielectric constant?
Question 33.Explanation:
Capacitance, C = epsilom x area of plates distance between the two plates

The relationship between C and epsilon (εo) is in direct variation

X1/ε1 = C2/ε2

20/1 = 60 /ε2

= 20 = 60/ ε2

Ε2 = 3.0

9.6A
14.4A
1.0A

Question 34.Question: In the circuit above, three resistor, 2Ω, 4Ω and 12 Ω are connected in parallel and a 12V battery is connected across the combination. The current flowing through 12Vbattery is
Question 34.Explanation:
Total resistance, 1/R = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3 (The resistors are connected in parallel)

1/R = 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/12

1/R = 10/12

R = 12/10

R = 6/5Ω

Voltage in a circuit is given as

V = I (R + r)

I = V/ (R + r)

I= 12/(12 + 6/5)

= 0.9A

= 1.0 A

Options.Value: ₦16
₦240
₦28
₦12

Question 35.Question: If the charge of electricity per kWh is ₦400, what is the cost of operating an electrical appliance rated 2.50V, 2A for 6hours?
Question 35.Explanation:
Total power consumed is given as

P = IV

= (2x 2.5)w = 5 watts

Total energy consumed = power x time

= 5 x 6

=30 w/hr.

= 0.03Kw/hr

Price = 0.03 x 400

= N12

Question 36.Question: The correct expression for potential at a point, distance r from a charge q in an electric field is
Question 36.Explanation:
Electric potential is the work done in taking a unit mass or charge from infinity to that point

v = kq/r

q = charge

r = distance

k = constant = 1/4πɛor

v = q/4πɛor

Since it is at a distance r from the charge, the notation is negative.

Question 37.Explanation:
Total internal resistance is

R = 2/3

= 0.66 Ω

= 0.7 Ω

Total EMF = 2v + 2v + 2v

= 6v

Question 39.Explanation: Short-sightedness usually occurs when the eyes grow slightly too long. Question 44.Question: In an a.c. circuit, the ratio of r.m.s value of peak value of current is
Question 44.Explanation: The root mean square (rms) of current in an a.c circuit is given as 1/√2. It is also known as the "equivalent" or "d.c equivalent" value of an a.c voltage or current. Question 46.Question: Under which of the following conditions do gases conduct electricity?
Question 46.Explanation: Gases conduct electricity only under low pressure and high voltage (potential difference). Gases begin to conduct electricity at low pressure because colliding electrons can acquire higher kinetic energy due to increased mean free path leading to ionisation of atoms. The electrical conductivity is due to the migration of electrons and positively charged ions under the influence of an electrical field.

Question 47.Explanation: The moving iron ammeter is designed to measure high frequencies in an alternating current circuit. Moving iron instruments indicate the rms value of any a.c waveform applied. Moving iron ammeters are commonly used to measure current in industrial frequency a.c circuits.

Question 50.Question: The electrical properties of germanium can be altered drastically by the addition of impurities. The process is referred to as
Question 50.Explanation: In semiconductor production, doping is the intentional introduction of impurities into an intrinsic semiconductor for the purpose of modulating its electrical, optical and structural properties. The doped material is referred to as an extrinsic semiconductor.
